Award.AwardTitle: Social Integration, Stress, and Ambition in Transitions to Adulthood

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

This study examines how youths' stress exposure, social integration, and aspirations affect their well-being as they transition to adulthood. We focus on youth in an isolated rural region where communities that were once sustained by jobs in pulp and paper mills have experienced the closing of these mills in recent years. Our research explores how youth outcomes,such as health, deviancy, education, and work,are related to family-, school-, and community-related stress experiences, integration, and aspirations. Building on the stress-process literature in sociology, this research likewise examines how sex, age, and socioeconomic differences in well-being are linked to stress, social integration, and aspirations. Finally, this research examines the degree to which links between stress exposure and the above forms of well-being differ depending on youths' levels of social integration and aspirations.

We build on an existing two-wave population-based quantitative survey of youth who were in 7th and 11th grades in 2008, and on qualitative interviews with a subsample of 24 7th graders and their mothers. We will collect an additional wave of survey data from the original youth participants, and conduct follow-up interviews with the original qualitative study participants. Our interdisciplinary (e.g., Sociology, Justice Studies, Family Studies, and Education) and mixed-method approach will allow us to examine in-depth and over time the experiences relevant for successful transitions to adulthood in an understudied population facing a unique set of economic and developmental challenges.

The broader impacts of our study include our involvement of undergraduate and graduate student assistants across all phases of the research, ranging from data collection and management to analysis and dissemination. Benefits to students include various opportunities to complete senior, MA, and PhD theses and dissertations, and many other possibilities for collaboration on research and outreach with faculty and community leaders. Senior faculty researchers will continue to disseminate project information, results, and policy-relevant material via scholarly journals and national conference presentations, on which student co-authorship across disciplines will be a priority. In addition, our team will continue to establish and foster local collaborative partnerships with the long-term goal of designing, implementing, and evaluating innovative interventions that promote the successful transition to adult roles in rural Communities facing unique economic challenges. In keeping with the University of New Hampshire Carsey Institute's mission of "building knowledge for families and communities," the information gleaned from the project will be the subject of presentations, lectures, policy briefs, and other public service activities relevant to the promotion of youth and young adult well-being locally and nationally. The project will promote scientific inquiry and practice by contributing to stress and life course theory, research, and policy development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using quantitative and qualitative research methodologies, this work applied sociological stress and life course frameworks to better understand personal (physical, psychological), interpersonal (behavioral, family), and social (educational, occupational) well-being in youth and emerging adulthood. We collected five waves of survey data from two youth cohorts (beginning in 2008, when respondents were in 7th and 11th grades) to examine the roles and significance of perceived integration (sense of belonging within community, school, and family contexts) and aspirations (future goals and ambitions concerning education, work, family, and residence) in the “stress process” over time. Survey data were collected in 2008, 2009, 2011, 2013, and 2015. In addition, we collected semi-structured qualitative interviews with: a subsample of the original 7th graders and their mothers in 2008 and again in 2014 (about 1 year after the 7th graders had finished high school), and; a subsample of the original 11th graders in 2010 (about 1 year after completing high school). We focused on youth residing in a rural northern New England county, a geographically isolated area of increasing economic decline and job loss, at a time when the financial situations of parents and neighbors were likely to deteriorate further, and at a stage of the life course when aspirations and perceptions of educational and economic opportunities are shaped and realized.

 

The intellectual merit of the proposed work derived, in part, from our focus on a population of youth and emerging adults in this rural context, which provided fertile ground for examining stress processes and their intersection with individual, family, school, and community resources and constraints. Among other things, findings from our research show that community, school, and family contexts are vital for personal, interpersonal, and social well-being for rural youth and young adults. With regard to community context: a sense of community attachment reduced risk for teen depression, substance misuse, and delinquency, and it buffered the harmful effects of stress exposure on substance misuse, especially for boys; consistent involvement in outdoor activities fostered youth expectations regarding their future opportunities and educational achievement (aspirations), and it reduced their risk for marijuana use, and; a breadth of involvement in both organized and unstructured leisure activities increased teens’ positive perceptions about the future and reduced their risk for depression, substance use, and poor physical health. With regard to school context: a sense of school belonging was associated with a decreased risk for teen depression, substance use, and aggressive behavior, and; school connectedness in youth increased positive perceptions about local job prospects in young adulthood, especially for the older cohort. With regard to family context: a sense of attachment to parents and siblings among teens in low socioeconomic (low-SES) positions reduced their odds of obesity and substance misuse; for high-SES teens, parental and sibling attachment reduced their odds of depression; sibling aggression was associated with poorer physical, psychological, and behavioral health, and; household chaos was related to poorer health and less positive beliefs about the future.

 

Several broader impacts of the proposed work were realized. Our study drew on undergraduate and graduate student assistance as an integral part of research (data collection, management, and analysis) and outreach (policy-related publications and presentations). Benefits to students included opportunities to complete MA and PhD theses and dissertations and for collaboration on research and outreach with faculty and community leaders. Senior faculty researchers continue to disseminate project information, results, and policy-relevant material via scholarly journals and national conference presentations, on which graduate student co-authorship across disciplines (e.g., Sociology, Justice Studies, and Family Studies) is a priority. In addition, our team continues to establish and foster local collaborative partnerships with the long-term goal of designing, implementing, and evaluating innovative interventions that promote the successful transition to adult roles. The information gleaned from this project continues to be the subject of various presentations, lectures, policy briefs, and other public service activities relevant to the promotion of youth and young adult well-being locally and nationally.
